sentences.text: The 2021 Canadian federal election, held on September 20, 2021, saw only minor changes from the preceding 2019 Canadian federal election|2019 election. The incumbent Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal Party, led by Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, did not win the popular vote and failed to win enough seats to gain a parliamentary majority, winning only a plurality of seats and retaining its status as a minority government. The Conservative Party of Canada |Conservative Party won the popular vote and continued as the Official Opposition (Canada)|Official Opposition.{{efn|name=LPC seat count}} In March 2022, the Liberals struck a deal with the fourth-place New Democratic Party (NDP), where the latter would provide confidence and supply for the duration of the Parliament in exchange for certain policy concessions. The agreement lasted until September 2024, when the NDP terminated the deal.

sentences.text:
{{main|2024â€“2025 Canadian political crisis|2025 Liberal Party of Canada leadership election}}
The government was plunged into a political crisis on December 16, 2024, when finance minister Chrystia Freeland abruptly resigned, only hours before she was set to present the government's fall economic statement, due to her opposition to Trudeau's fiscal policy. Trudeau, who had already faced down a caucus revolt in October, was faced with renewed questions about his leadership. By December 22, 21 Liberal MPs had publicly called for Trudeau to step down. On January 6, 2025, Trudeau announced his intention to resign as prime minister after the party elected his successor. The ensuing leadership election was won by Mark Carney, former governor of the Bank of Canada. Carney was sworn in as prime minister on March 14.

sentences.text:
{{See also|Electoral Participation Act#Movement of fixed election date}}
Under the Fixed election dates in Canada|fixed-date provisions of the ''Canada Elections Act'', which requires federal elections to be held on the third Monday in October in the fourth calendar year after the polling day of the previous election, the election was scheduled to take place on October 20, 2025. However, elections can occur before the scheduled date if the Governor general of Canada|governor general dissolves Parliament on the recommendation of the prime minister, either for a List of snap elections in Canada|snap election or after the government loses a vote on a Loss of supply|supply bill or a specific motion of no confidence.

sentences.text: On March 20, 2024, the government introduced the ''Electoral Participation Act'', which included an amendment to the ''Canada Elections Act'' that would have changed the fixed election date to October 27, 2025, to avoid conflicting with Diwali, as well as 2025 Alberta municipal elections|municipal elections in Alberta. The bill died on the Order Paper|order paper when the Parliament of Canada was Prorogation in Canada|prorogued by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau after he announced his resignation.

sentences.text: Canada's electoral system, a "First-past-the-post voting|first-past-the-post" system, is formally referred to as a single-member plurality system. Voters select a representative nominated for their Electoral district (Canada)|electoral district (sometimes referred to as a ''riding''), and the candidate with more votes than any other candidate is elected to a seat in the 343-member House of Commons and represents that riding as its member of Parliament (MP). The party that wins the most seats in the House of Commons usually forms government, with that party's leader becoming Prime Minister (Canada)|prime minister. The largest party by seat count that is not the government or part of a governing coalition becomes the Official Opposition. That party receives more finances and privileges than the other opposition parties.

sentences.text:
{{main|2022 Canadian federal electoral redistribution}}

This will be the first election contested under the new electoral districts established in the 2022 redistribution. Consequently, media outlets tend to report seat gains and losses as compared to Notional election results|notional results. These are the results if all votes cast in 2021 were unchanged but regrouped by new electoral district boundaries, as published by Elections Canada.

*December 5 â€“ The People's Party concluded its leadership review of Maxime Bernier. He was confirmed and continued as leader.

May became leader and Pedneault deputy leader of the Green Party of Canada, pending a change to the party's constitution to allow co-leadership.

sentences.text:
* Launch a "Canada Strong Pass", available from June to August 2025, that grants children and youth under the age of 18 free access to national galleries and museums, as well as free seats on trains operated by Via Rail when traveling with their parents.
* Reduce lowest income tax bracket from 15% to 14% 
* Eliminate the Goods and services tax (Canada)|GST on new home purchases under $1-million for first-time home buyers
* Create a crown corporation, Build Canada Homes, to serve as a housing developer overseeing affordable housing construction.
* Offer $25 billion in financing for prefabricated housing and $10 billion for affordable homebuilding.
* Increase annual funding for Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC/Radio-Canada by {{CAD|150 million}}, and enshrine such funding in law.

sentences.text:
{{main|Canadian leaders' debates#2025 debates}}
In its May 2022 report, the Leaders' Debates Commission recommended various improvements for future debates, and that it remain a permanent publicly funded entity to organize leaders' debates. In October 2024, the Leaders' Debate Commission announced that the English-language debate would be hosted by TVO's Steve Paikin, while the French-language debate would be hosted by Ici RDI's Patrice Roy.

sentences.text: On April 1, 2025, the Commission announced that it had invited the leaders of the Bloc QuÃ©bÃ©cois, Conservative Party, Green Party, Liberal Party, and New Democratic Party to the debates. Invitations were issued on the basis of meeting at least two of three conditions: having at least one sitting MP, recording at least 4% support in national opinion polling, and endorsing candidates in at least 90 percent of ridings. The Green Party's invitation was rescinded on April 16 as it ultimately ran candidates in 232 ridings (less than 70 percent) despite earlier submitting to the Commission that it would run candidates in every riding. The People's Party was not invited, as it did not meet the criteria for either holding a seat in Parliament or polling at least 4%.<ref name="DebateInvites"/>

sentences.text: On April 15, the leaders of the Bloc QuÃ©bÃ©cois and the NDP suggested rescheduling the French language debate because of the debate coinciding with the final ice hockey|hockey game of the Montreal Canadiens' regular season, after it became clear the game would decide whether the Canadiens would make the 2025 Stanley Cup playoffs|playoffs. The Commission declined to reschedule the debate to a different day, but agreed to move the start time two hours earlier to 6:00 pm Eastern Daylight Time|EDT.

sentences.text: A post-debate news scrum after the French language debate was allegedly dominated by Rebel News and other independent media outlets, considered to be "far-right", leading to complaints from mass news media at the event. Later, David Cochrane (journalist)|David Cochrane of CBC News asked Michel Cormier, the debate commissionâ€™s executive director, about the fairness of the distribution of questions among outlets and the type of questions asked. Cormier stated, "There's only so much we can do to control free speech."  Cormier, claimed he was "unaware" that Rebel News and another organization associated with Rebel founder Ezra Levant were registered as third-party advertisers with Elections Canada. During the English language debate the next day, there was a reported disturbance in the media centre concerning the distribution of questions and Levant's alleged election interference. Cormier felt "a proper environment" could not be guaranteed and abruptly cancelled the planned news scrum, as Montreal Police secured the venue.
